metadata.case_name: Mahant Moti Das & Ors. v. State of Bihar & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant in C.A. No. 225/55 is Mahant Moti Das, Mahant of a math or asthal in village Parbatta, district Monghyr, Bihar, follower of religion founded by Sri Kabir Sahib, properties treated as private properties of mahants, President of Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts served notice under s.59 of the Act claiming no authority as Act ultra vires and inapplicable.

Appellant in C.A. No. 226/55 is Mahant Ram Das, mahant of math or asthal in village Bhuthari, district Monghyr, bairagi sadhu and follower of Ramanandi Laskari Sri Vaishnava Sampradaya, absolute owner of properties belonging to math, President issued notice asking for statements and accounts of properties.

In C.A. No. 228/55, appellants challenged vires of Act in suit originally in Subordinate Judge Patna, transferred to High Court under Art. 228, cause of action date of President's assent published in Bihar Gazette.
Appellant in C.A. No. 229/55 is Mahant Mahabir Das, Mahant of Bisanpur Asthal in district Monghyr, received notice from President to furnish statements and accounts, challenged vires.

Appellant in C.A. No. 248/55 is Mahant Ram Krishna Das, temple Bhikam as Thakurbari in Patba constructed by Benidasji with own money, installed deities, temple and properties not religious trust under Act, Act ultra vires infringing fundamental rights.
Defence in all cases: Act valid and applies to asthals or temple and properties.
In M.J.C. 418/52 (C.A. 225/55), counter-affidavit by State that asthal public and properties trust properties.
In M.J.C. 124/53 (C.A. 226/55), similar claim of absolute ownership countered.
In Suit No. 34/52-106/53 (C.A. 228/55), prayer to amend plaint to claim private character disallowed by High Court.
In M.J.C. 188/53 (C.A. 229/55), claim no express or implied trust.
In M.J.C. 235/53 (C.A. 248/55), counter-affidavit that temple public and Act applies.
Act passed by Bihar Legislature, President's assent published February 21, 1951, came into force August 15, 1951.
High Court judgments: October 5, 1953 (two), October 8, 1953 (one), held Act valid, dismissed writs and suit.
Certificates under Art. 132 granted by High Court.

legal_issues.text: Constitutional validity of Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 (Bihar I of 1951)
Whether ss.2,5,6,7,8 infringe Art.14 (classification excluding Sikhs, separate Boards for Jains)
Whether Chapter V, ss.28,32 violate Art.19(1)(f) (restrictions on right to hold/dispose trust properties)
Whether provisions violate Arts.25,26 (freedom of religion, manage affairs)
Whether s.70 imposes unauthorised tax, violates Art.27
Whether properties are private or trusts public/private, applicability of Act

petitioner_arguments.text: ss.2,5,6,7,8 infringe Art.14: definition of Hindu excludes Sikhs; separate Boards for Swetambar/Digambar Jains differ from general Hindu Board; inequality between Hindus/Sikhs/Jains.
Chapter V (ss.28,32) etc. violate Art.19(1)(f): mahant/shebait loses management rights, reduced to servant; interferes with proprietary right in trust properties.
Provisions violate Arts.25,26: interfere with profess/practice religion, manage religious affairs/denominations.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arts.25,26; Shirur Mutt, Ratilal Panachand Gandhi

petitioner_arguments.text: s.70 imposes unauthorised tax >5% net income, violates Art.27.
s.55(2) contravenes Art.133 by barring further appeals.
Properties are private properties of mahants or private trusts, not public religious trusts under Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Act valid, applies to asthals/temples and properties as public religious trusts.
Differences in faith/practices/organization justify classification excluding Sikhs, separate Jain Boards.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14; Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Tendolkar

respondent_arguments.text: Restrictions reasonable under Art.19(5) for better administration/protection of trusts.

court_reasoning.text: Art.14 challenge rejected: reasonable classification based on differences in faith, practices, organization between Hindus, Sikhs, Jains; Sikhs excluded as no need, Jains have separate organizations; presumption of constitutionality.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification founded on intelligible differential with rational relation to object.

court_reasoning.text: Art.19(1)(f) challenge rejected: restrictions on trustees reasonable under Art.19(5) for better administration, protection/preservation of trust properties; shebait has office+property but subject to duties; Act provides speedy remedy vs s.92 CPC; safeguards like District Judge appeals.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions carry out trust objects, unlike invalid Madras/Orissa Acts.

court_reasoning.text: Arts.25,26 not violated: no interference with religious practices/beliefs; powers subject to founder's wishes/law; ensures proper administration per trust purposes; no diversion of funds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Apprehension of abuse doesn't invalidate; Act implements trust, doesn't defeat.

court_reasoning.text: s.70 is fee not tax (per Orissa case); not hit by Art.27 as for secular administration, not promoting religion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fee for administration, not merged in general revenue.

court_reasoning.text: s.55(2) doesn't override Art.133 or Supreme Court jurisdiction.
Nature of trusts (public/private) requires factual inquiry/evidence, not for writs; suit amendment disallowed; Act applies to public trusts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No materials to determine; appeals turn on Act's validity.

holdings.text: Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 constitutionally valid; doesn't infringe Arts.14,19(1)(f),25,26,27; s.70 fee not tax; s.55(2) doesn't bar SC appeals.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.14: reasonable classification test, presumption of constitutionality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Shri Shirur Mutt
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.19 restrictions unreasonable in Madras Act; religious practices protected but not here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahant Shri Jagannath Ramanuj Das v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Fee vs tax distinction; s.49 Orissa Act valid, Art.27 not violated.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Venkataramana Devaru v. State of Mysore
Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Right to manage includes spending per founder; no diversion here.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 (Bihar Act I of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned Act held valid for better administration of Hindu religious trusts.

statutes_cited.name: Religious Endowments Act, 1863 (20 of 1863)
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed/amended by s.4; s.92 CPC no longer applies per s.4(5).

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior machinery for trusts; Act provides better remedy.

statutes_cited.name: Charitable and Religious Trusts Act, 1920 (14 of 1920)

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 constitutionally valid, rejecting all challenges under Arts.14,19,25,26,27,133; questions of private/public nature remitted for factual inquiry elsewhere; appeals dismissed as High Court correctly upheld Act.

key_quotes.text: "Art.14 forbids class legislation... but does not forbid reasonable classification... founded on an intelligible differential... rational relation to the object."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The restrictions imposed by the Act... are really for the purpose of carrying out the objects of the trust and for better administration... reasonable restrictions... within Art.19(5)."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The keynote of all the relevant provisions of the Act is the due observance of the objects of the religious trust and not its breach or violation."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The shebait has not only duties... but he has a beneficial interest... proprietary right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Nature of shebait rights, but subject to regulation.
